articles.headline: Banks Tried to Kill Crypto and Failed. Now They’re Embracing It (Slowly).
articles.snippet: Digital payments technology is forcing the financial system to evolve. Banks feel their power waning and want to regain control.
articles.abstract: Digital payments technology is forcing the financial system to evolve. Banks feel their power waning and want to regain control.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2014, as regulators in New York were exploring ways to control Bitcoin, executives at Wall Street’s biggest banks fretted that regulating cryptocurrencies would also legitimize them — and that could threaten the finance industry. So they tried to sow doubt.

articles.headline: BIPOC or POC? Equity or Equality? The Debate Over Language on the Left.
articles.snippet: For those pushing for changes in society on race and other issues, words matter. They can also muddle.
articles.abstract: For those pushing for changes in society on race and other issues, words matter. They can also muddle.
articles.lead_paragraph: In California, a Black college freshman from the South is telling a story about his Latino friends from home when he is interrupted by a white classmate. “We say ‘Latinx’ here,” he recalls her saying, using a term he had not heard before, “because we respect trans people.”

articles.headline: James Staley, Barclays’s C.E.O., steps down after a Jeffrey Epstein inquiry.
articles.snippet: British regulators investigated how the bank executives characterized his ties with the disgraced financier.
articles.abstract: British regulators investigated how the bank executives characterized his ties with the disgraced financier.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than two years after Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in a Manhattan jail cell, the consequences of associating with the convicted sex offender continue to reverberate through the highest echelons of the business world.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Supreme Court Hints That It May Allow Challenge to Texas Abortion Law
articles.snippet: In two arguments on Monday, the justices considered challenges from abortion providers and the Biden administration to a law that bans abortions after about six weeks.
articles.abstract: In two arguments on Monday, the justices considered challenges from abortion providers and the Biden administration to a law that bans abortions after about six weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After almost three hours of lively arguments on Monday at the Supreme Court, a majority of the justices seemed inclined to allow abortion providers — but perhaps not the Biden administration — to pursue a federal court challenge to a Texas law that has sharply curtailed abortions in the state.

articles.headline: The TV Hit That Wasn’t
articles.snippet: There was a lot of advance hype for the FX series “Impeachment: American Crime Story.” But it won’t be available on any major streaming platform for another 10 months, and that’s a problem in 2021.
articles.abstract: There was a lot of advance hype for the FX series “Impeachment: American Crime Story.” But it won’t be available on any major streaming platform for another 10 months, and that’s a problem in 2021.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was one of the most dramatic episodes of the season. Monica Lewinsky, the heroine of “Impeachment: American Crime Story,” strikes an immunity deal with federal prosecutors, and President Bill Clinton admits to having had an affair to a grand jury and the nation as a whole. The episode also brought Hillary Clinton, portrayed by Edie Falco, to center stage for the first time.

articles.headline: After the Flood, It’s Not Just ‘About the Coming Back’
articles.snippet: Following the devastation wrought by Hurricane Ida in Millburn, N.J., small business owners are facing an uncertain future, even as the community rallies to help.
articles.abstract: Following the devastation wrought by Hurricane Ida in Millburn, N.J., small business owners are facing an uncertain future, even as the community rallies to help.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILLBURN, N.J. — To survive the pandemic’s waves, Kevin Cao, the owner of Thai House Restaurant, halted dine-in service, cut five staff members and kept his drunken noodles, pad thai and curry moving with curbside pickup and delivery.

articles.headline: Europe Fears That Rising Cost of Climate Action Is Stirring Anger
articles.snippet: Memories of the Yellow Vest movement are prompting officials to ensure that spiking energy prices don’t fuel inequality or populist discontent.
articles.abstract: Memories of the Yellow Vest movement are prompting officials to ensure that spiking energy prices don’t fuel inequality or populist discontent.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Raucous demonstrations against high energy bills in Spain. Demands for social protection in Greece as coal mines close. Fresh protests in French rural areas and small towns over spiking petrol prices.

articles.headline: How the Pandemic Has Added to Labor Unrest
articles.snippet: While big companies wield considerable power, Covid’s economic disruption has given workers new leverage, contributing to a recent upturn in strikes.
articles.abstract: While big companies wield considerable power, Covid’s economic disruption has given workers new leverage, contributing to a recent upturn in strikes.
articles.lead_paragraph: When 420 workers at the Heaven Hill spirits bottling plant near Louisville went on strike in September, they were frustrated that the company’s proposed contract could reduce their overtime pay. Many had earned extra income working seven days a week during the pandemic.
